INDV has managed to maintain its market position until mid-February although Dr Reddy’s, Mylan and Alvogen have now entered the market, along with an authorised generic from Sandoz. The slower than expected erosion, along with royalties on the authorised generic, is an important source of cash in 2019 that was not expected at the beginning of the year.

We estimate sales of $66m in 2019 and peak sales of c.$600m in our base case (180p).

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If you can bring the case in multiple states the plaintiff can introduce racketeering which multiplies the original damage value - if I remember correctly. I had a laugh once reading about a house buyer that was a plaintiff in a racketeering case because his house had to be fitted with a sewage pump which his wife and himself couldn't possibly be seen to own. What on Earth would they do if there was a power cut! LOL

The gist is that UnitedHealth said "hey, free universal healthcare would be pretty bad for our business, which is to charge people money for healthcare".

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Policy announcements from DC are driving
movement in the managed care space (see the chart below). Headlines related to Medicare for All are likely to continue for the foreseeable future,
but it is still not going to become a reality in the next five years. Senator Sanders is viewed as a front-runner for the Democratic nomination and
multiple Democratic candidates (Senators Booker, Gillibrand, Harris, and Warren) have cosponsored the bill. As campaign rallies are held, the
topic is likely to continue to be raised. What the market has shown us this week is that the negative sentiment is not going to change as companies
beat and increase earnings because the sentiment is impacted by Washington alone.

BE11:29am

Soundbuy Fevertree lively on a lacklustre day +2%.........though vols a tad lacklustre.......

BE11:30am

Chill, they say, because politics can always be counted to lean towards the status quo.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Since introducing the legislation, Senator Sanders has discussed using the reconciliation process to advance the bill through Congress. As a
reminder, reconciliation only requires a simple majority vote to pass the Senate (at least 50 Senators, with the Vice President acting as the tie
breaker), and this maneuver can only be used a limited number of times per year. The reconciliation process bypasses the filibuster. To accomplish
this, he would have to have senators change the reconciliation rules to allow this to occur. The President does not get to set Senate rules so he
would need a majority to be willing to make this change. We also note that several Democratic senators have already come out against MFA, which
means that the Democrats will likely need to lock up more than a simple majority for any change to the senate rules. While only needing 50 instead
of 60 votes would make passing it easier, we have always believed that the next time any one party controls the House, Senate, and Presidency;
the legislative filibuster will largely go away. Therefore, Senator Sander's comments do not change our calculus.

BE11:39am

Operational issues at Wipac have continued in Q4
Technical Plastics and Aerospace Divisions performed in line with expectations, with technical Plastics enjoying a much-improved performance in H2. However, the operational issues at Wipac have continued through the final quarter. Although Wipac production volumes have increased in recent weeks, customer backlogs remain largely unchanged, reflecting increased demand, partly for Brexit-related safety stock reasons. Following a number of personnel changes, the Board is confident of further progress being made in improving output in the near term.
Year-end net debt was in line with expectations but covenant test deferred Net debt at 31 March was in line with the Board’s expectations, at slightly above the level at the half year. The banks remain supportive and have deferred the year-end covenant test to allow the Group time to seek early customer
reimbursement of monies incurred by Wipac for the design and development of future production programmes. Had the test been applied at 31 March, we
expect the outcome would have been borderline.
10% cut to Mar 2019 PBT to £6.3m
In light of the additional costs incurred at Wipac and slightly higher central costs, we have cut our Mar 2019 PBT by 10% to £6.3m (new EPS of 6.5p). We have also cut our Mar 2020 PBT by 8% to £6.9m (7.2p). We feel it is prudent at this stage to assume no overall improvement Wipac profits next year but anticipate continued growth in Technical Plastics and a stable performance in Aerospace.

BE11:40am

Going long here seems to be a bet on management both fixing the constantly malfunctioning business in the very short term and getting a refinancing away that leaves something for shareholders.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Moneysupermarket has reported 12% organic growth in Q1, a further acceleration from 2% in Q3 and 7% in Q4. There is some lumpiness to this – Home Services has been extremely strong in Q1 (+70%) and should unwind somewhat, likely particularly in Q3. But the progress shown in Q4 around improving conversion rates driving better growth across the verticals is continuing: Money has accelerated in Q1 and the core Home & Motor categories of Insurance would have been notably better than the headline +3% reported for that vertical (life insurance has declined materially). Guidance for the year is unchanged and our forecasts don't move much (up 1%, in line with cons). But the sense of confidence in execution is improving. The share price already reflects this: the stock is up 25% YTD but good delivery helps justify the move. To merit a material further rerating from here (currently 19x P/E and 4.7% FCF yield in 2019) would need more evidence of a material growth acceleration – we are building confidence. We stay EW and nudge up our PT with slightly higher outer years.

4% Q1 revenue beat driven by Home Services. Q1 rev growth of 19% is 12% organic ex Decision Tech. We had 8% organic. Home Services grew 70% vs our 13% - March has been very strong with the price cap increase on April 1. Some of this will flow into April, but then logically May could be tougher. And Q3 faces a very tough comp from 2017+18 - we model clearly down. So some of this is phasing - but it is always good to see phasing have a positive impact. Insurance grew 3% vs our 9% but was impacted by weak life (we think motor & home were likely up higher single digits – broadly as we expected). Money grew 9%: encouraging. Travel (-16%) is weak but small.

No change to guidance. Moneysupermarket remain "confident of meeting current market expectations": revenue of £388m, EBITDA of £141m (though with some different assumptions on IFRS 16), EPS of 18.5p (not materially impacted by IFRS 16). They are clear they expect Home Services growth to moderate after the bumper Q1.

Only minor changes to forecasts. Before including IFRS 16 into our model, our EBITDA and EPS increases 1% with revenues unchanged. Then we run through IFRS 16 so headline EBITDA goes up 3% and EPS still up 1%.

£40m cash return will be a special dividend. As we already modelled – 7.5p (as reminder, the cash return was announced at FY results). Shares go ex-div on 2 May.

Bluesky21 And Admiral founder's wife buying a stake in their price comparison website last Nov make me suspect there is still money in the space
BE11:57am

And Numis.

BE11:58am

In terms of divisions it was Home Services that stood out, up an exceptionally strong +70%, driven by a combination of attractive offers in the period and the announcement of the price cap increase. Insurance was solid, and as expected at +3%, with strong motor insurance partially offset by subdued trading in life insurance as competitors spent more on customer incentives. Money was strong at +9% against a soft 2108 comp. Other revenues were boosted by £6.2m contribution from Decision Technologies

Outlook comments note the exceptional performance in Q1 from Home Services, and an expectation that this growth will moderate as we move through the year (Q3 in particular a tough comp). Management confirm an unchanged outlook for the year. The Board remains confident of meeting market expecations.

All in a very strong Q1 that firmly underpins estimates for the year with risk on the upside as we move into H1 results. Moneysupermarket is a key large cap pick for us, we reiterate our BUY and 390p target.
